comment_data.body: I find it easier to process that `client.enable(timeout)` will use whatever `client.exit_timeout` is as a default.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -281,8 +282,12 @@ LSP
   takes too long to shutdown after being disabled.
 • Push diagnostics (|vim.lsp.diagnostic.on_publish_diagnostics()|) now respect
   the `version` property in the notification params.
-• |vim.lsp.ClientConfig| has an `exit_timeout` field to control the timeout of
-  client force stopping. Defaults to 3000 milliseconds.
+• |vim.lsp.ClientConfig| `exit_timeout` field controls the time waited before
+  force-stop is invoked on a server by `enable(false)` and at Nvim shutdown.
+  The `exit_timeout` field graduated from "experimental" `flags.exit_timeout`
+  to a top-level field.
+• |vim.lsp.enable()| with `enable=false` force-stops the server after
+  a timeout, unless unless `flags.exit_timeout=false`.

comment_data.body: This paragraph is a bit strange and seems like an unfinished Vim feature that Bram had in mind 20 years ago that, AFAIK, doesn't work. Or else it's just copy-paste that no one ever noticed. It talks about "hot-link" to a command, but backticks don't create a hotlink, and the block just above this already describes how to create hotlinks.

comment_data.body: It would be more robust to mention the `help-codeblock` section here instead of "see below".
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -481,15 +481,12 @@ aligned on a line.
 When referring to an existing help tag and to create a hot-link, place the
 name between two bars ("|") eg. |help-writing|.
 
-When referring to a Vim command and to create a hot-link, place the
-name between two backticks, eg. inside `:filetype`.  You will see this is
-highlighted as a command, like a code block (see below).
-
 When referring to a Vim option in the help file, place the option name between
 two single quotes, eg. 'statusline'
 
-When referring to any other technical term, such as a filename or function
-parameter, surround it in backticks, eg. `~/.path/to/init.vim`.
+When referring to any other technical term or symbol, such as a filename or
+function parameter, surround it in backticks, eg. `~/.path/to/init.vim`. This
+renders it as "inline" code (as opposed to a "codeblock", see below).

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
    To disable, pass `enable=false`: stops related clients and servers (and force-stop servers after a timeout, unless `exit_timeout=false`).
```
Since force-stop is the new default, removing the "may" here feels more appropriate.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1016,8 +1016,11 @@ config({name}, {cfg})                                       *vim.lsp.config()*
       • {cfg}   (`vim.lsp.Config`) See |vim.lsp.Config|.
 
 enable({name}, {enable})                                    *vim.lsp.enable()*
-    Auto-starts LSP when a buffer is opened, based on the |lsp-config|
-    `filetypes`, `root_markers`, and `root_dir` fields.
+    Auto-activates LSP in each buffer based on the |lsp-config| `filetypes`,
+    `root_markers`, and `root_dir`.
+
+    To disable, pass `enable=false`: stops related clients and servers (and
+    may force-stop servers after a timeout, unless `exit_timeout=false`).

comment_data.body: Force-stop only occurs if the server does not gracefully stop. It's somewhat vague but don't want to over-explain, for now at least.

comment_data.body:
The use of "may" here feels ambiguous:
```suggestion
    force-stop servers after a timeout, unless `exit_timeout=false`).
```
Removing it entirely makes it clearer that this is the default unless `exit_timeout` is disabled.

comment_data.body:
Did you mean
```
char *Versions[] = { "8.1", "8.2", "9.0", "9.1" };
```
to remove `"8.1"`?
That's automated too.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -239,6 +239,34 @@ Some github labels are used to trigger certain jobs:
 * `needs:response` - close PR after a certain amount of time if author doesn't
   respond
 
+Vim patches
+-----------
+
+Multiple Vim versions are tracked in `version.c`, so that `has('patch-x.y.z')`
+works even if `v:version` is "behind". Whenever we "complete" merging all
+patches from a Vim `v:version`, the steps to bump `v:version` are:
+
+1. Remove the fully-merged version from `version.c:Versions`.

comment_data.body: What steps are needed to remove a version?

comment_data.body:
Your step 2 should suffice.
I noted https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/36585#discussion_r2540783336 because vimpatch.lua depends on `sort` for 1st patch.
1st patch (ie. `bash ./scripts/vim-patch.sh -M | head -n 1`) defines the minimum version for `Versions[0]`, `vim_versions[0]`.
If `version.c` requires multi-line version arrays, then update `vimpatch.lua` to sync its output with `make formatc.`

These arrays always have the same size to search by index.
No bounds assertions though since code assumes no manual edits.

comment_data.body: step 2 doesn't seem like enough because it only modifies `scripts/vimpatch.sh`, but `scripts/vimpatch.lua` is what generates `version.c` ...

comment_data.body:
True.
Step 3 is required so that maintainer does not need a `version.c` MR to publish a release.

I am only saying that  `step 1` is redundant.
If `version.c` does need these manual edits, then vimpatch.lua missed edge cases during the refactor.
As long as vimpatch.lua can make Nvim jump to the correct lines and run the correct commands,
It should work on empty/incomplete arrays and generate the same result (assuming no merged vim-patch tokens like v8.2.0000).

comment_data.body: `vim.lsp.enable()` does not accept a force argument. This change only applies to `Client:stop()`. You can only change `vim.lsp.enable()`'s timeout with `client.exit_timeout`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -274,14 +275,16 @@ LSP
 • Support for `textDocument/onTypeFormatting`: |lsp-on_type_formatting|
   https://microsoft.github.io/language-server-protocol/specification/#textDocument_onTypeFormatting
 • The filter option of |vim.lsp.buf.code_action()| now receives the client ID as an argument.
-• |Client:stop()| now accepts a numerical `force` argument to be interpreted
-  as the time to wait before forcing the shutdown.
+• |Client:stop()| and |vim.lsp.enable()| accept `force` as an integer, which is
